  <b:widget id='PopularPosts1' locked='false' title='Popular Posts' type='PopularPosts'>
    <b:includable id='main'>
<b:if cond='data:title'><h2><data:title/></h2></b:if>
  <div class='widget-content popular-posts'>
    <ul>
      <b:loop values='data:posts' var='post'>
      <dd>
        <b:if cond='data:showThumbnails == "false"'>
          <b:if cond='data:showSnippets == "false"'>
            <!-- (1) No snippet/thumbnail -->
            <a expr:href='data:post.href'><data:post.title/></a>
          <b:else/>
            <!-- (2) Show only snippets -->
            <div class='item-title'><a expr:href='data:post.href'><data:post.title/></a></div>
            <div class='item-snippet'><data:post.snippet/></div>
          </b:if>
        <b:else/>
          <b:if cond='data:showSnippets == "false"'>
            <!-- (3) Show only thumbnails -->
            <div class='item-thumbnail-only'>
              <b:if cond='data:post.thumbnail'>
                <div class='item-thumbnail'>
                  <a expr:href='data:post.href' target='_blank'>
                    <img alt='' border='0' expr:height='data:thumbnailSize' expr:src='data:post.thumbnail' expr:width='data:thumbnailSize'/>
                  </a>
                </div>
              </b:if>
              <div class='item-title'><a expr:href='data:post.href'><data:post.title/></a></div>
            </div>
            <div style='clear: both;'/>
          <b:else/>
           <!-- (4) Show snippets and thumbnails -->
        <b:if cond='data:post.thumbnail'>
            <img expr:alt='data:post.title' expr:src='data:post.thumbnail' height='50' width='50'/>
<b:else/>
            <img alt='no image' height='50' src='http://lh4.ggpht.com/_u7a1IFxc4WI/TTjruHJjcfI/AAAAAAAAAk0/i11Oj6i_bHY/s50/no-image.png' width='50'/>
        </b:if>
        <a expr:href='data:post.href' expr:title='data:post.snippet' rel='bookmark'><data:post.title/></a>
            <div style='clear: both;'/>
          </b:if>
        </b:if>
      </dd>
      </b:loop>
    </ul>
  </div>
</b:includable>

</b:section-contents><b:section-contents id='sidebar-right-2-1'>
  <b:widget id='BlogArchive1' locked='false' title='Blog Archive' type='BlogArchive'>
    <b:includable id='main'>
        <b:if cond='data:title'>
          <h2>
            <data:title/>
          </h2>
        </b:if>
        <div class='widget-content'>
          <div id='ArchiveList'>
            <div expr:id='data:widget.instanceId + "_ArchiveList"'>
              <b:if cond='data:style == "HIERARCHY"'>
                <b:include data='data' name='interval'/>
              </b:if>
              <b:if cond='data:style == "FLAT"'>
                <b:include data='data' name='flat'/>
              </b:if>
              <b:if cond='data:style == "MENU"'>
                <b:include data='data' name='menu'/>
              </b:if>
            </div>
          </div>
          <b:include name='quickedit'/>
        </div>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='flat' var='data'>
        <ul class='flat'>
          <b:loop values='data:data' var='i'>
            <li class='archivedate'>
              <a expr:href='data:i.url'>
                <data:i.name/>
              </a>
              (
              <data:i.post-count/>
              )
            </li>
          </b:loop>
        </ul>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='interval' var='intervalData'>
        <b:loop values='data:intervalData' var='i'>
          <ul class='hierarchy'>
            <li expr:class='"archivedate " + data:i.expclass'>
              <b:include data='i' name='toggle'/>
              <a class='post-count-link' expr:href='data:i.url'>
                <data:i.name/>
              </a>
              <span class='post-count' dir='ltr'>
                (
                <data:i.post-count/>
                )
              </span>
              <b:if cond='data:i.data'>
                <b:include data='i.data' name='interval'/>
              </b:if>
              <b:if cond='data:i.posts'>
                <b:include data='i.posts' name='posts'/>
              </b:if>
            </li>
          </ul>
        </b:loop>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='menu' var='data'>
        <select expr:id='data:widget.instanceId + "_ArchiveMenu"'>
          <option value=''>
            <data:title/>
          </option>
          <b:loop values='data:data' var='i'>
            <option expr:value='data:i.url'>
              <data:i.name/>
              (
              <data:i.post-count/>
              )
            </option>
          </b:loop>
        </select>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='posts' var='posts'>
        <ul class='posts'>
          <b:loop values='data:posts' var='i'>
            <li>
              <a expr:href='data:i.url'>
                <data:i.title/>
              </a>
            </li>
          </b:loop>
        </ul>
      </b:includable>
    <b:includable id='toggle' var='interval'>
        <b:if cond='data:interval.toggleId'>
          <b:if cond='data:interval.expclass == "expanded"'>
            <a class='toggle' href='javascript:void(0)'>
              <span class='zippy toggle-open'>
                ▼ 
              </span>
            </a>
            <b:else/>
            <a class='toggle' href='javascript:void(0)'>
              <span class='zippy'>
                <b:if cond='data:blog.languageDirection == "rtl"'>
                  ◄ 
                  <b:else/>
                  ► 
                </b:if>
              </span>
            </a>
          </b:if>
        </b:if>
      </b:includable>
  </b:widget>
</b:section-contents><b:section-contents id='sidebar-right-2-2'/><b:section-contents id='sidebar-right-3'/><b:section-contents id='footer-1'/><b:section-contents id='footer-2-1'/><b:section-contents id='footer-2-2'/></html>

Convert JPEG byte array to image
entry.content:
This bug takes me one week to fix. 
Usually when you want to read the image stream via http, you can use the Java self contained ImageIO class to do it. I tried to find the similar class used in Android, which is called the BitmapFactory, and there is a problem. I got a byte array of size over 30000, and when I tried to use BitmapFactory.decodeByteArray(), it failed. But it worked when using ImageIO.read(byteArrayStream). Strangely enough, it takes me four days to figure out what's going wrong. By figuring out, I mean staring at the monitor and falling asleep. On Friday, I thought it might be a good idea to take a look at what is the difference between the original byte array and the byte array after the processing of ImageIO. Eureka. It turned out that the first 22 bytes are different. The JPEG has standard byte array marker, the first two bytes are 0xff and 0xd8. Somewhere after 20 bytes there are two bytes 0xff and 0xdb. The 18 bytes between 0xd8 and 0xff are the difference. The 18 bytes in the processed byte array are: 0xff, 0xff, 0x00, 0x10, 0x4a, 0x46, 0x49, 0x46, 0x00, 0x01, 0x02, 0x00, 0x00, 0x01, 0x00, 0x01, 0x00, 0x00. Those bytes have replaced the original bytes between two markers. So I changed the bytes between 0xd8 and 0xff in the original byte array. And Eureka. Actually when I deleted the bytes between 0xd8 and 0xff in the original byte array, it still worked. I guess those 18 bytes must be some garbage bytes added into the array when the bytes are generated but I don't know exactly the reason why. ImageIO seems to be able to dismiss and correct the garbage data in the byte array but not the BitmapFactory. This is misleading because if you think ImageIO works you will probably think BitmapFactory will work too. But actually it is not and it hurts my feeling. So never underestimate the difficulty of small or trivial task. Detail is your best teacher. 
I feel better when this one is solved after being under the weather for the whole week. Catching cold is not something serious, but sometimes can be tough to get away.

link.title: Convert JPEG byte array to image

entry.title: FTP send command bug on Android
entry.content:
Recently I met with a bug when trying to communicate with another device on Android using FTP. When I tried to send the FTP command PORT to the device on Android phone it simply gave me back NoResponseException. The FTP command is sent using Socket and it is simple three lines of code. 
                    commandOutput.write("port xxx,xxx,xxx,xxx,xxx,xxx");                
                    commandOutput.newLine();
                    commandOutput.flush();

commandOutput is the BufferedWriter object, it simply writes the command code to the socket and then jumps to the new line. It seems to be right but it just doesn't work. Somehow it worked perfectly when I changed the code to the following:
            
commandOutput.write("port xxx,xxx,xxx,xxx,xxx,xxx");                
commandOutput.write("
");
commandOutput.flush();
The only change is the second line, an " " is added before " " which together seems to have the same function as the mere " ". The original one works well on the desktop but fails on Android, the new one works well on both so I guess there may be some issues about the use of BufferedWriter which are Android specific. And that one line change saves me out of the trouble of FTP failure on Android which stupefies me for days. Strange indeed.

link.title: FTP send command bug on Android

entry.title: Add external custom Android UI into your app
entry.content:
I happen to know that there are tons of nice and beautiful Android custom UI widgets and views on GitHub. Basically each widget is an Android application and you can actually import it into your own app to make your app look better. I want to try the Circular Progress Button which is a well made button widget to indicate the progress of a certain time consuming process if you click it. It's easy to use it, what you need to do is to add a tag with the name of the widget in your layout xml file. And the block of widget in xml looks like this:
<com.dd.CircularProgressButton
    android:id="@+id/btnWithText"
    android:layout_width="196dp"
    android:layout_height="64dp"
    android:layout_marginTop="16dp"
    android:textColor="@color/white"
    android:textSize="18sp"
    app:cpb_textComplete="@string/Complete"
    app:cpb_textError="@string/Error"
    app:cpb_textIdle="@string/Upload" />
The problem is, however, how to import the project that contains the code of view building into your project. Normally we configure the Java Build Path and include the external library and project to make it work. When I try to include the project into the build path, it fails to recognize the external widget class. After trying different ways, I happened to find that there is a Is Library checkbox in the Properties window under the Android tab and there is a Add button on the right. I thought maybe I should click the checkbox and then import it as a library like it said in my own project. So I did select the checkbox in the external widget project like the following.


Another thing I need to do right now is to add this library project into my project which is very intuitive. And it turned out to look very promising like this with a green check mark:


It really worked and I could use the widget conveniently afterwards.

link.title: Add external custom Android UI into your app

entry.title: Application cast
entry.content:
When I try to use the application singleton class in an Android project, I come across the ClassCastException error. What I want to do is to cast the system application class to my own application class which is made to keep the data consistent. I try to do this: 

((MyApplication) getApplication()).setMyCurrentObject(myCurrentObject);
Somehow the system doesn't know my own application class and it fails. After some search, it turns out to be that the name of the system application is not defined in the AndroidManifest.xml. So in the manifest file you have to add the value called name in the applicaiton tag and it will be good, like this:

 
<application android:icon="@drawable/icon" android:label="@string/app_name"
    android:name=".MyApplication">

entry.title: QuickBlox user sign up and sign in
entry.content:
I was trying QuickBlox these days and I just found there seemed to be two ways to sign into the QuickBlox server and one of them turned out doesn't work. 
This the one that works:
 final QBUser user = new QBUser(username, password);

    QBAuth.createSession(user,
      new QBEntityCallbackImpl<QBSession>() {
       @Override
       public void onSuccess(QBSession session, Bundle args) {

        user.setId(session.getUserId());

        loginToChat(user);

       }

       @Override
       public void onError(List<String> errors) {

       }
 });


This is the one that doesn't:
 QBAuth.createSession(new QBEntityCallbackImpl<QBSession>() {
      @Override
      public void onSuccess(QBSession session, Bundle args) {

       final QBUser user = new QBUser(username, password);

       QBUsers.signIn(user, new QBEntityCallbackImpl<QBUser>() {
          @Override
          public void onSuccess(QBUser user,
            Bundle args) {

          loginToChat(user);

          }

          @Override
          public void onError(List<String> errors) {
          
          }

        });
      }

      @Override
      public void onError(List<String> errors) {
       
      }
  });

The one that doesn't work uses the following method:
QBUsers.signIn(User user, Callback callback)
But this method doesn't seem to work at all. The actual procedure of signing in is as follows. First you create a session in order to open up the connection with the XMPP server. Then you have to sign in a registered user into the connection with XMPP which called the transfer from application session to user session. After being transferred to the user session, you will be able to get the access to the user backend and implement all kinds of functions. So the signing in is the most important.  
The other way of signing in is to directly create the user session along with application session using the method that creates the applications session:
QBAuth.createSession(User user, Callback callback)
It can take in either one parameter of two, if it takes two, the first parameter will be signing in user object and if it takes one, there will be no user object taken in. We no longer need QBUsers.signIn() method because we will sign in to the user session if the QBAuth.createSession() method takes in the user object parameter. 
As for the signing up, which is used for creating new user in backend, there is no problem. There is a method similar to QBUsers.signIn() called QBUsers.signUp() and can be used intuitively:
 QBAuth.createSession(new QBEntityCallbackImpl<QBSession>() {
      @Override
      public void onSuccess(QBSession session, Bundle args) {

       final QBUser user = new QBUser(newUsername, newUserPassword);

       user.setEmail(email);

       QBUsers.signUp(user, new QBEntityCallbackImpl<QBUser>() {
          @Override
          public void onSuccess(QBUser user,
            Bundle args) {
         
          }

          @Override
          public void onError(List<String> errors) {
           
          }

        });
      }

      @Override
      public void onError(List<String> errors) {
      
      }
 });
The conclusion is, if you want to sign in as registered user or sign up as new user, you definitely have to create the session and it will let the backend know which user is currently as active as on the client side. Signing up is intuitive but signing in right now is not. If we can use QBUsers.signIn() method it will be more intuitive. 
By the way, whenever you insert the code inside the html, remember to change the < with < and > with >.

link.title: QuickBlox user sign up and sign in

entry.title: A film called Passion Play
entry.content:
I somehow couldn't sleep at last night, switching TV channels again and again. Then I saw Mickey Rourke's twisted face with a white top hat and it caught my attention instantly. He was walking alone in suit like a poor and abandoned jazz player in 80's. The color of the scene was so ethereal and vague and it gave me kind of feeling that it might be an pretty old movie. Then the screen suddenly lit up when Mickey saw a woman standing behind the exhibition glass with a pair of wings waving on her back and it caught my attention massively. I felt like I've seen that woman in other films but couldn't remember who she is and the wing on her back was just making her look like a heavenly angel. After a series of boring plots played, the beautiful woman eventually carried Mickey with her flying in the sky and the last scene of the film revealed the truth that Mickey actually saw his body lying in the desert as they flew over. I think that ending as well as the angel girl might be the only highlight of the film and besides these this film was the worst film I have ever seen. When the credit of the film showed, I saw the actress's name and it was Megan Fox as expected. I knew that the director wanted to plot a story of the lightning before death but there was no clue at all for me why should put a woman with real wing into that. Metaphor of something or just director's wired fantasy? I just don't get it. But what I get is that Megan Fox's pretty face became the fantasy in my dream. 
Today I search about the film and what makes me more surprised is that this film is a 2010 year production and it looks like 1980. IMDb score is 5 out of 10 and I think it is unsurprising at all and pretty decent.

entry.title: Indenticon
entry.content: Yesterday I came up with an idea when I was roaming around on GitHub. Looking at the avatar of my GitHub account, I thought what does it really mean. After some research I knew it actually means something and has a name. Identicon, which basically is the combination of identity and icon, is your unique avatar that contains your personal information. There is a kind of way of encrypting the information into a series of rambling characters that almost means nothing called SHA hashing. Using this way of hashing, a string can be converted into a several byte codes of specific length and therefore we can actually fill in the 5 by 5 square avatar according to the byte codes' positivity. If it is positive we fill in the block with color and leave it empty otherwise. In order to make sure the avatar is symmetrical and therefore better looking, we only do the left three columns and make the mirror of left two columns and apply it to the right two. I think the number of generated byte codes are 20, and I only use the first 15 of them. I wrote a wrapper class of generating the identicon and the output of my name turned out to be very like the letter Y, which can very well personalize me because Y is my initial. Very interesting indeed.

entry.title: Google GCM not found
entry.content:
Today when running the MAF application on emulator, I encountered an error message like this.  

BUILD FAILED
C:\Users\ZhangY\workspace\BarcodeDemo\.main.android\bin\build-android.xml:42: The following error occurred while executing this line:
C:\Users\ZhangY\AppData\Local\Android\sdk\tools\ant\build.xml:720: The following error occurred while executing this line:
C:\Users\ZhangY\AppData\Local\Android\sdk\tools\ant\build.xml:734: C:\Users\ZhangY\AppData\Local\Android\sdk\extras\google\gcm\gcm-client\dist does not exist.

It simply says that I lost the Google GCM(Google Cloud Messaging) SDK. The normal way to solve this is to look into the SDK manager and download the required SDK. It should be in the Extras folder but what I saw was this:



There seems to be no GCM, right? Then I searched on Google and find the answer. 


Simply tick the button called Obsolete.




There you go.
By the way I also learned how to add a piece of code into the blog with actual the code look thanks to the SyntaxHighligher and a blog talking about how to embed. It's a little bit cumbersome to use but I think I will get used to it later.

entry.title: My first blog
entry.content:
This is my first blog and it is a good sign of the advent of my everyday writing habit. I will probably write mainly in English and sometimes in Chinese. Topics may vary from technical experiences to daily life. An article that strikes me talks about how important it is to keep blogging as a habit. It kind of reminds me of the old days that I first touched blogging in my middle school. It was called QQ Space. Actually it was a part of extension of QQ IM app and I just wrote something there and I felt pretty cool. It was basically all meaningless sentimental words that portraits a fifteen year old teenager inside world and I now look back and feel like pretty stupid but still want to get back if there is a time machine. In future I think blogging will be sort of my personal journal which keeps track of my thought and memory which is a good thing. Also it is a good way to write down some technical issues and problems to keep me alert every now and then. I will definitely forget how to write with a pen as I stroke more and more keyboard and I don't think it is something bad. At least it will help my fingers become more flexible which is a good thing when I am coding most of the day. I can also pick up my habit back in undergraduate when I like to write some piece of fictions every now and then. What's different from that time is that now I have grasp another tool to express myself by coding and I believe those two things, writing and coding, are essentially the same thing, they are the carriers of the thought. Code can be more concrete by defining clear structure and naming properly and writing can be abstract if you disassemble the structure of the article and using vague words. After all, the brain is the master of both kinds of work and they can't get out of the barriers set by ourselves.
Anyway, today is start of something new, perhaps I will see after ten years.
